description: a(1)=3, b(n)=Product_{k=1..n} a(k), a(n+1)=largest prime factor of b(n)-1.
references: R. K. Guy and R. Nowakowski, Discovering primes with Euclid, Delta (Waukesha), Vol. 5, pp. 49-63, 1975.
Des MacHale, Infinitely many proofs that there are infinitely many primes, Math. Gazette, 97 (No. 540, 2013), 495-498.
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
S. S. Wagstaff, Jr., Computing Euclid's primes, Bull. Institute Combin. Applications, 8 (1993), 23-32.
maple: with(numtheory):a:= proc(n) option remember;      `if`(n=1, 3, max(factorset(mul(a(i), i=1..n-1)-1)[]))    end:seq(a(n), n=1..10);  # _Alois P. Heinz_, Sep 26 2013
mathematica: a[0] = 3; a[n_] := a[n] = Block[{p = Times @@ (a[#] & /@ Range[0, n - 1]) - 1}, FactorInteger[p][[-1, 1]]]; Array[a, 13] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Sep 26 2013 *)
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_.
extensions: a(14) from Joe K. Crump (joecr(AT)carolina.rr.com), Jul 26, 2000
